title: Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models in Six Simple Steps
abstract: Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPMs) are a very popular class of deep generative model that have been successfully applied to a diverse range of problems including image and video generation, protein and material synthesis, weather forecasting, and neural surrogates of partial differential equations. We assume that the reader is familiar with fundamental topics in machine learning including basic probabilistic modelling, Gaussian distributions, maximum likelihood estimation, and deep learning.

title: Adapting to Unknown Low-Dimensional Structures in Score-Based Diffusion   Models
abstract: This paper investigates score-based diffusion models when the underlying target distribution is concentrated on or near low-dimensional manifolds within the higher-dimensional space in which they formally reside, a common characteristic of natural image distributions. All of this is achieved by a novel set of analysis tools that characterize the algorithmic dynamics in a more deterministic manner.

title: Structured Denoising Diffusion Models in Discrete State-Spaces
abstract: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) (Ho et al. 2020) have shown impressive results on image and waveform generation in continuous state spaces. The third allows us to draw a connection between diffusion models and autoregressive and mask-based generative models. We show that the choice of transition matrix is an important design decision that leads to improved results in image and text domains. We also introduce a new loss function that combines the variational lower bound with an auxiliary cross entropy loss. For text, this model class achieves strong results on character-level text generation while scaling to large vocabularies on LM1B. On the image dataset CIFAR-10, our models approach the sample quality and exceed the log-likelihood of the continuous-space DDPM model.

title: Improved Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models
abstract: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) are a class of generative models which have recently been shown to produce excellent samples. We show that with a few simple modifications, DDPMs can also achieve competitive log-likelihoods while maintaining high sample quality. Additionally, we find that learning variances of the reverse diffusion process allows sampling with an order of magnitude fewer forward passes with a negligible difference in sample quality, which is important for the practical deployment of these models. We additionally use precision and recall to compare how well DDPMs and GANs cover the target distribution. Finally, we show that the sample quality and likelihood of these models scale smoothly with model capacity and training compute, making them easily scalable. We release our code at https://github.com/openai/improved-diffusion

Name: adaptive_coordinate_embeddings

Problem Statement: Fixed sinusoidal embeddings for spatial coordinates may not optimally represent geometric relationships in low-dimensional data for diffusion models, particularly for datasets with varying local structures.
Motivation: Learned coordinate embeddings could better adapt to local geometric structures in the data distribution, potentially improving sample quality and convergence. This is particularly relevant for low-dimensional diffusion models where spatial relationships are crucial.
Proposed Method: Replace the fixed sinusoidal coordinate embeddings with learned embeddings implemented as a small MLP that maps coordinates to embedding space. Time embeddings remain fixed to isolate the effect of coordinate adaptation.
Experiment:
1. Implement LearnedCoordinateEmbedding class as a small MLP
2. Modify MLPDenoiser to use the new embedding only for spatial coordinates
3. Compare against baseline using KL divergence and sample quality metrics
4. Visualize learned embedding patterns across different regions of space
5. Analyze performance across different dataset types (uniform vs. clustered distributions)

Name: classifier_guided_lowdim_diffusion
Title: Classifier-Guided Diffusion for Controllable Low-Dimensional Generation
Problem Statement: Current low-dimensional diffusion models generate samples unconditionally, lacking mechanisms to control which modes or regions of the distribution are sampled from.
Motivation: Adding control to generation would make these models more useful for applications where we want to target specific regions of the data space, while maintaining the benefits of diffusion models for low-dimensional data.
Proposed Method: Extend the existing diffusion model with classifier guidance by training a simple separate classifier on the data modes, then using its gradients during sampling to bias generation towards desired regions.
Experiment:
1. Train a simple classifier to distinguish data modes
2. Modify NoiseScheduler.step() to incorporate classifier gradients
3. Evaluate with metrics for both sample quality and control accuracy
4. Visualize guided vs unguided samples for interpretability

Name: learned_schedule_endpoints
Title: Learning Optimal Noise Schedule Endpoints for 2D Diffusion Models
Problem Statement: Fixed noise schedule endpoints in diffusion models may not be optimal for all 2D data distributions, potentially affecting both training efficiency and sample quality.
Motivation: Different 2D datasets may require different noise schedule characteristics - learning just the endpoints while keeping the interpolation fixed provides a practical way to adapt to dataset specifics without excessive complexity.
Proposed Method: Modify the NoiseScheduler to learn only the beta_start and beta_end parameters during training, while maintaining either linear or quadratic interpolation between them. The parameters would be optimized to minimize the denoising loss.
Experiment:
1. Extend NoiseScheduler to make beta_start/beta_end learnable parameters
2. Add optimization of these parameters in the training loop
3. Compare learned endpoints across different 2D datasets
4. Evaluate impact on training convergence and sample quality
5. Analyze correlation between learned endpoints and dataset statistics

Name: confidence_weighted_diffusion
Title: Confidence-Weighted Denoising for Adaptive Low-Dimensional Diffusion
Problem Statement: Fixed-weight denoising in diffusion models doesn't account for varying prediction certainty across different regions of low-dimensional data.
Motivation: By weighting denoising steps based on prediction confidence, we can focus model capacity where it's most needed, potentially improving sample quality in complex regions.
Proposed Method: Extend the denoiser to output confidence scores and use them to weight the denoising updates, with higher confidence predictions having greater influence.
Experiment:
1. Modify MLPDenoiser to output confidence scores alongside noise predictions
2. Adapt the training loss to incorporate confidence weighting
3. Compare sample quality metrics with and without confidence weighting
4. Visualize confidence patterns across different 2D datasets
5. Analyze correlation between confidence and local data density/curvature

abstract: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) (Ho et al. 2020) have shown impressive results on image and waveform generation in continuous state spaces. Here, we introduce Discrete Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (D3PMs), diffusion-like generative models for discrete data that generalize the multinomial diffusion model of Hoogeboom et al. 2021, by going beyond corruption processes with uniform transition probabilities. This includes corruption with transition matrices that mimic Gaussian kernels in continuous space, matrices based on nearest neighbors in embedding space, and matrices that introduce absorbing states. The third allows us to draw a connection between diffusion models and autoregressive and mask-based generative models. We show that the choice of transition matrix is an important design decision that leads to improved results in image and text domains. We also introduce a new loss function that combines the variational lower bound with an auxiliary cross entropy loss. For text, this model class achieves strong results on character-level text generation while scaling to large vocabularies on LM1B. On the image dataset CIFAR-10, our models approach the sample quality and exceed the log-likelihood of the continuous-space DDPM model.

title: Improved Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models
abstract: Denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) are a class of generative models which have recently been shown to produce excellent samples. We show that with a few simple modifications, DDPMs can also achieve competitive log-likelihoods while maintaining high sample quality. Additionally, we find that learning variances of the reverse diffusion process allows sampling with an order of magnitude fewer forward passes with a negligible difference in sample quality, which is important for the practical deployment of these models. We additionally use precision and recall to compare how well DDPMs and GANs cover the target distribution. Finally, we show that the sample quality and likelihood of these models scale smoothly with model capacity and training compute, making them easily scalable. We release our code at https://github.com/openai/improved-diffusion
